user_query: What is the mechanism of viroid replication?
chatgpt_response: The mechanism of viroid replication involves the transcription of the viroid RNA by cellular RNA polymerase II, followed by the processing of the viroid RNA by cellular enzymes to generate unit-length circular RNA strands. These circular RNA strands then serve as templates for the replication of new viroid RNA molecules. In the case of Avsunviroidae viroids, the multimeric replicative intermediates of either polarity generated in plastids self-cleave through hammerhead ribozymes to facilitate replication.

user_query: Describe Canvas SPW
chatgpt_response: Canvas SPW is a retrospective observational study conducted in a tertiary referral centre to evaluate the characteristics of bronchial angiograms in the setting of systemic artery-pulmonary circulation shunts (SPS) and the safety and effectiveness of bronchial artery embolisation (BAE) for patients with life-threatening haemoptysis. The study found that BAE using polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) was successful in 97.8% of the patients with SPS and had high rates of freedom from recurrence at 1 month, 1 year, and 2 years. The study concluded that BAE with PVA was safe and effective for life-threatening haemoptysis complicated by SPS, regardless of the specific type of SPS complication.

user_query: Describe SLIC-CAGE
chatgpt_response: The SLIC-CAGE is a multifunction lid that has been developed for a commercially available transparent animal cage. It is designed to permit feeding, watering, viewing, long-term holding, and local transport of laboratory rodents while isolating the surrounding environment. The cage is airtight except for its inlet and exhaust high-efficiency particulate air filters, and it is completely steam-sterilizable. The ventilation system design allows for the holding of animals infected with different organisms without the danger of cross-contamination. The system also reduces the need for chemical vapor decontamination, keeps the animal room odor-free, and reduces the required bedding changes to twice a month or less. The caging system can hold 48 cages and can be conveniently placed on a standard NIH "shoebox" cage rack. It is mobile and only requires an electrical power outlet. The principal application of the caging system is in preventing exposure of animal caretakers to pathogenic substances associated with the animal host and in reducing the handling of animals and their exposure to extraneous contamination.

user_query: What is the use of the Liverpool Elbow Score?

It incorporates both patient perception and clinician assessment and is sensitive to change on treatment. It includes a nine-item patient questionnaire and a six-item clinical evaluation, and has been shown to have good test-retest reliability, internal consistency, and convergent validity with other scores such as the Disabilities of Arm, Shoulder and Hand Questionnaire and the Nottingham Health Profile.

user_query: Describe efforts on Sarcoma from the 100,000 Genomes Project
chatgpt_response: The 100,000 Genomes Project has focused on studying the suppression of genes involved in tumor progression, metastasis formation, and therapy resistance through RNA interference. They have developed a method of systemic application of shRNA expression plasmid via tail vein injection in xenograft mice, leading to sustained reduction of target gene expression in primary tumors. The project has specifically targeted the S100A4 gene, which drives metastasis in colorectal cancer. By reducing S100A4 expression in tumor tissues by 30%, they have seen a 70% decrease in liver metastases. In vivo imaging of bioluminescent cancer cells has allowed for monitoring of tumor growth and metastasis formation over time, with end point analysis including scoring of metastatic burden and quantification of target gene expression in the tumor. These efforts represent promising progress in the field of sarcoma research and may ultimately lead to improved therapeutic strategies for cancer treatment.

This is due to the improved diagnostic capacity of CT, which reduces the number of undetected tumor cases. However, the use of CT has also been linked to a decrease in the incidence of malignant tumors, such as neuroepithelial tumors. Therefore, while head CT may increase the detection of certain types of brain tumors, it does not directly increase the overall risk of developing a brain tumor.

user_query: Is progeria caused by an autosomal recessive gene?
chatgpt_response: No, progeria is not caused by an autosomal recessive gene. It is caused by mutations in the LMNA gene, specifically the activation of a cryptic splice site resulting in the in-frame loss of 150 nucleotides from the lamin A message. This mutation leads to the abnormal farnesylation of the protein progerin, which is implicated in the cellular phenotype of HGPS. This indicates that progeria is caused by a specific mutation in the LMNA gene rather than being inherited as an autosomal recessive trait.

user_query: What are common variants at 12q14 and 12q24 associated with?
chatgpt_response: Common variants at 12q14 and 12q24 are associated with an increased risk of developing a second primary malignancy (SPM) after an index squamous cell carcinoma of the head and neck (SCCHN). Specifically, patients with variant genotypes of the p14(ARF) rs3731217 and rs3088440 single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) had a significantly reduced SPM-free survival and a moderately increased risk of developing an SPM. Furthermore, patients with combined variant genotypes of the two SNPs were at an even greater risk of developing an SPM. Therefore, p14(ARF) polymorphisms at 12q14 and 12q24 may serve as susceptible markers for the risk of SPM in patients with SCCHN.
